title: Ext vanishing and infinite Auslander-Buchsbaum
summary:

algebras. Along the way, an "infinite" version is proved of the non-commutative

arXiv:math/0304168v1 [math.RA] 14 Apr 2003

EXT VANISHING AND INFINITE
AUSLANDER-BUCHSBAUM
PETER JØRGENSEN
Abstract. A vanishing theorem is proved for Ext groups over
non-commutative graded algebras. Along the way, an "infinite"
version is proved of the non-commutative Auslander-Buchsbaum
theorem.

0. Introduction
Let R be a noetherian local commutative ring, and let X be a finitely
generated R-module of finite projective dimension. The classical Auslander-Buchsbaum theorem states
pd X = depth R − depth X.
This can also be phrased as an Ext vanishing theorem, namely, if M is
any R-module, then
ExtiR (X, M) = 0 for i > depth R − depth X.

(1)

In [1] is proved a surprising variation of this: Suppose that R is
complete in the m-adic topology. Then equation (1) remains true if X
is any R-module of finite projective dimension, provided M is finitely
generated. In other words, the condition of being finitely generated is
shifted from X to M.
In theorem 2.4 below, this result will be generalized to the situation
of a non-commutative noetherian N-graded connected algebra.
The route goes through an "infinite" version of the non-commutative
Auslander-Buchsbaum theorem, given in theorem 1.4. This result is a
substantial improvement of the original non-commutative AuslanderBuchsbaum theorem, as given in [3, thm. 3.2], in that the condition of
dealing only with finitely generated modules is dropped.
The notation of this paper is standard, and is already on record in
several places such as [2] or [3]. So I will not say much, except that
throughout, k is a field, and A is a noetherian N-graded connected

Remark 1.5. Theorem 1.4 even holds for depth A = ∞, where the
theorem states depth X = ∞.
On the other hand, suppose depth A < ∞. Then it is easy to see
that it makes sense to rearrange the equation in theorem 1.4 as
k.fd X = depth A − depth X.
If the cohomology of X is bounded and finitely generated, then this
equation reads
pd X = depth A − depth X
by remark 1.2. This is the original non-commutative Auslander-Buchsbaum theorem, as proved in [3, thm. 3.2].

The following is the special case of theorem 2.3 where X and M
are concentrated in degree zero, that is, where X and M are graded
modules.
Theorem 2.4 (Ext vanishing). Assume that A satisfies depth A < ∞
and dimk ExtiA (k, A) < ∞ for each i.
Let X in Gr(A) have fd X < ∞, and let M be in gr(A). Then
ExtiA (X, M) = 0 for i > depth A − depth X.

 8

PETER JØRGENSEN

This says that for fd X < ∞, the number depth A − depth X plays
the role of projective dimension of X, but only with respect to finitely
generated graded modules M.
Of course, this fails when M is general, as illustrated by the following
example.
Example 2.5. Let A be the polynomial algebra k[x]. Then the conditions of theorem 2.4 are satisfied, and it is classical that depth A is
1.
Let X be k[x, x−1 ]. Then depth X ≥ 1 because X is a graded torsion
free module, so depth A − depth X ≤ 0 and theorem 2.4 gives
ExtiA (X, M) = 0 for i > 0
for M in gr(A).
However, this must fail when M is general, for otherwise X would
be a projective object of Gr(A) which it is certainly not.
